oneLeg.name: Long Call
oneLeg.description: Simplest bullish strategy. Buys the right, but not the obligation, to purchase the underlying asset at the strike price before expiration. Used when expecting a significant rise in the underlying price.

oneLeg.name: Short Put
oneLeg.description: Collects premium by selling the obligation to buy the underlying asset if it falls below the strike price. Profitable if the underlying stays above the strike price. High potential risk if the price drops significantly.

oneLeg.name: Short Call (Naked)
oneLeg.description: Collects premium by selling the obligation to sell the underlying asset if it rises above the strike price. Profitable if the underlying stays below the strike price. High, theoretically unlimited risk if the price rises significantly.

oneLeg.name: Long Put
oneLeg.description: Simplest bearish strategy. Buys the right, but not the obligation, to sell the underlying asset at the strike price before expiration. Used when expecting a significant fall in the underlying price.

oneLeg.name: Covered Call
oneLeg.description: Selling a call option against shares of the underlying stock already owned. Generates income (premium) and provides limited protection against a price decline. Limits upside profit potential. Note: This strategy is typically used with stocks, not futures like MES, and requires owning the underlying asset.
oneLeg.maxProfit: Strike Price + Premium Received - Stock Purchase Price
oneLeg.example: Own 100 shares of XYZ bought at $100. Sell 1 XYZ 105 Call for $1.50.

oneLeg.name: Cash-Secured Put
oneLeg.description: Selling a put option and setting aside enough cash to buy the underlying shares if assigned. A way to potentially buy shares at a discount (the strike price) while collecting premium. Similar profit/loss to a Covered Call, but doesn't require owning stock upfront.
construction: Hold cash equivalent to Strike Price * 100 (notional value)
oneLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 104.50 (Bid), holding cash/margin equivalent.

twoLeg.name: Bull Call Spread (Vertical Debit)
twoLeg.description: A defined-risk bullish strategy. Buys a call at a lower strike and sells a call at a higher strike (same expiration). Cheaper than a long call, but profit potential is capped.
twoLeg.maxProfit: Difference between strikes (K2 - K1) - Net Debit Paid
twoLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5960 Call for 93.75 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5980 Call for 78.00 (Bid). Net Debit: 93.75 - 78.00 = 15.75.

twoLeg.name: Bear Put Spread (Vertical Debit)
twoLeg.description: A defined-risk bearish strategy. Buys a put at a higher strike and sells a put at a lower strike (same expiration). Cheaper than a long put, but profit potential is capped.
twoLeg.maxProfit: Difference between strikes (K2 - K1) - Net Debit Paid
twoLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 109.50 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5960 Put for 100.00 (Bid). Net Debit: 109.50 - 100.00 = 9.50.

twoLeg.name: Bear Call Spread (Vertical Credit)
twoLeg.description: A defined-risk strategy that profits if the underlying stays below the short call strike. Sells a call at a lower strike and buys a call at a higher strike (same expiration) for protection. Entered for a net credit.
twoLeg.maxLoss: Difference between strikes (K2 - K1) - Net Credit Received
twoLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5990 Call for 73.00 (Bid), Buy 1 MES JUN13 6010 Call for 68.50 (Ask). Net Credit: 73.00 - 68.50 = 4.50.

twoLeg.name: Bull Put Spread (Vertical Credit)
twoLeg.description: A defined-risk strategy that profits if the underlying stays above the long put strike. Sells a put at a higher strike and buys a put at a lower strike (same expiration) for protection. Entered for a net credit.
twoLeg.maxLoss: Difference between strikes (K2 - K1) - Net Credit Received
twoLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 104.50 (Bid), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5950 Put for 100.75 (Ask). Net Credit: 104.50 - 100.75 = 3.75.

twoLeg.name: Long Straddle
twoLeg.description: Buying a call and a put with the same strike price and expiration date. Profits from a significant price move in either direction. Max loss is the total premium paid. Used when expecting a large move but uncertain of the direction.
twoLeg.maxProfit: Unlimited (Up); Strike Price - Net Debit Paid (Down)
twoLeg.breakeven: Lower: Strike K - Net Debit Paid; Upper: Strike K + Net Debit Paid
twoLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 88.25 (Ask), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 109.50 (Ask). Net Debit: 88.25 + 109.50 = 197.75.

twoLeg.name: Short Straddle
twoLeg.description: Selling a call and a put with the same strike price and expiration date. Profits from time decay and low volatility. Max profit is the total premium received. Risk is potentially unlimited.
twoLeg.maxLoss: Unlimited (Up); Strike Price - Net Credit Received (Down)
twoLeg.breakeven: Lower: Strike K - Net Credit Received; Upper: Strike K + Net Credit Received
twoLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 83.25 (Bid), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 104.50 (Bid). Net Credit: 83.25 + 104.50 = 187.75.

twoLeg.name: Long Strangle
twoLeg.description: Buying an OTM call and an OTM put with the same expiration date. Cheaper than a straddle but requires a larger price move to break even. Profits from significant volatility.
twoLeg.notes: K1 < K2. Both strikes are typically OTM relative to the current price.
twoLeg.maxProfit: Unlimited (Up); Lower Strike K1 - Net Debit Paid (Down)
twoLeg.breakeven: Lower: K1 - Net Debit Paid; Upper: K2 + Net Debit Paid
twoLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5960 Put for 105.00 (Ask), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5990 Call for 78.00 (Ask). Net Debit: 105.00 + 78.00 = 183.00.

twoLeg.name: Short Strangle
twoLeg.description: Selling an OTM call and an OTM put with the same expiration date. Profits from time decay and the underlying staying between the two strikes. Offers more room for the price to move than a short straddle but receives less premium. Risk is potentially unlimited.
twoLeg.notes: K1 < K2. Both strikes are typically OTM relative to the current price.
twoLeg.maxLoss: Unlimited (Up); Lower Strike K1 - Net Credit Received (Down)
twoLeg.breakeven: Lower: K1 - Net Credit Received; Upper: K2 + Net Credit Received
twoLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5960 Put for 100.00 (Bid), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5990 Call for 73.00 (Bid). Net Credit: 100.00 + 73.00 = 173.00.

threeLeg.name: Long Call Butterfly
threeLeg.description: A defined-risk strategy expecting the price to pin the middle strike at expiration. Profits from low volatility within a specific range. Typically involves a net debit.
threeLeg.notes: Strikes K1, K2, K3 are typically equidistant.
threeLeg.maxProfit: Middle Strike (K2) - Lower Strike (K1) - Net Debit Paid
threeLeg.breakeven: Lower: K1 + Net Debit Paid; Upper: K3 - Net Debit Paid
threeLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5960 Call for 93.75 (Ask), Sell 2 MES JUN13 5980 Calls for 78.00 (Bid) each, Buy 1 MES JUN13 6000 Call for 73.25 (Ask). Net Debit: (93.75 + 73.25) - (2 * 78.00) = 167.00 - 156.00 = 11.00.

threeLeg.name: Long Put Butterfly
threeLeg.description: Similar to the Call Butterfly but constructed with puts. Expects the price to pin the middle strike at expiration. Defined risk, typically entered for a net debit.
threeLeg.notes: Strikes K1, K2, K3 are typically equidistant.
threeLeg.maxProfit: Higher Strike (K3) - Middle Strike (K2) - Net Debit Paid
threeLeg.breakeven: Lower: K1 + Net Debit Paid; Upper: K3 - Net Debit Paid
threeLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5960 Put for 105.00 (Ask), Sell 2 MES JUN13 5980 Puts for 114.25 (Bid) each, Buy 1 MES JUN13 6000 Put for 129.75 (Ask). Net Debit: (105.00 + 129.75) - (2 * 114.25) = 234.75 - 228.50 = 6.25.

threeLeg.name: Call Ratio Spread (Debit)
threeLeg.description: Buying a call option at a lower strike and selling a greater number of call options at a higher strike (same expiration). Profits from a moderate move up, but faces significant risk if the price moves sharply above the higher strike. Can be entered for a net debit or credit.
threeLeg.notes: K1 < K2. Common ratio is 1:2, but can vary.
threeLeg.maxProfit: (K2 - K1) + Net Credit (if credit) or (K2 - K1) - Net Debit (if debit, achieved at K2)
threeLeg.breakeven: Calculated based on specific strikes, ratio, and net cost (see definition).
threeLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 88.25 (Ask), Sell 2 MES JUN13 5990 Calls for 73.00 (Bid) each. Net Credit: (2 * 73.00) - 88.25 = 146.00 - 88.25 = 57.75.

fourLeg.name: Iron Condor
fourLeg.description: A popular defined-risk, defined-profit strategy that benefits from time decay and low volatility. It involves selling an OTM Put Spread and an OTM Call Spread. The goal is for the underlying price to remain between the short strikes at expiration. Typically entered for a net credit.
construction: Sell 1 OTM Put (Lower Short Strike - K2)
Sell 1 OTM Call (Upper Short Strike - K3)
fourLeg.notes: K1 < K2 < Current Price < K3 < K4. Wings (K2-K1 and K4-K3) are often equal width.
fourLeg.maxLoss: Width of Widest Spread - Net Credit Received
fourLeg.breakeven: Lower: K2 - Net Credit Received; Upper: K3 + Net Credit Received
fourLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5940 Put for 96.50 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5960 Put for 100.00 (Bid), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5990 Call for 73.00 (Bid), Buy 1 MES JUN13 6010 Call for 68.50 (Ask). Net Credit: (100.00 + 73.00) - (96.50 + 68.50) = 173.00 - 165.00 = 8.00.

fourLeg.name: Iron Butterfly
fourLeg.description: A defined-risk, defined-profit strategy expecting minimal price movement and aiming for the underlying to expire exactly at the middle (short) strike. It combines a short ATM straddle (selling an ATM put and an ATM call) with protective OTM wings (buying a lower put and a higher call). Offers higher potential profit (credit) than an Iron Condor but requires a narrower price range. Typically entered for a net credit.
fourLeg.notes: K1 < K2 < K3. Wings (K2-K1 and K3-K2) are often equidistant. K2 is typically ATM.
fourLeg.maxLoss: Width of one Wing (e.g., K2 - K1) - Net Credit Received
fourLeg.breakeven: Lower: K2 - Net Credit Received; Upper: K2 + Net Credit Received
fourLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5950 Put for 100.75 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 104.50 (Bid), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 83.25 (Bid), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5990 Call for 78.00 (Ask). Net Credit: (104.50 + 83.25) - (100.75 + 78.00) = 187.75 - 178.75 = 9.00.

fourLeg.name: Reverse Iron Condor (Long Iron Condor)
fourLeg.description: A defined-risk strategy that profits from a significant price move in either direction (increased volatility). It's the opposite of a standard Iron Condor, constructed by buying the OTM Put Spread and buying the OTM Call Spread. This results in a net debit.
construction: Buy 1 OTM Put (Lower Short Strike - K2)
Buy 1 OTM Call (Upper Short Strike - K3)
fourLeg.notes: K1 < K2 < Current Price < K3 < K4. Opposite legs compared to standard Iron Condor.
fourLeg.maxProfit: Width of Widest Spread - Net Debit Paid (Reflects theoretical max payoff minus cost, actual max profit occurs outside wings)
fourLeg.breakeven: Lower: K1 + Net Debit Paid; Upper: K4 - Net Debit Paid
fourLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5940 Put for 91.50 (Bid), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5960 Put for 105.00 (Ask), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5990 Call for 78.00 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 6010 Call for 63.75 (Bid). Net Debit: (105.00 + 78.00) - (91.50 + 63.75) = 183.00 - 155.25 = 27.75.

fourLeg.name: Box Spread (Long)
fourLeg.description: Not a directional or volatility play. Combines a Bull Call Spread and a Bear Put Spread using the same two strikes. Theoretically locks in a risk-free profit equal to the difference between strikes minus the net debit paid. In practice, arbitrage opportunities are rare due to commissions and bid-ask spreads. Often used for financing purposes (creating a synthetic loan or deposit).
fourLeg.notes: All options must have the same expiration.
fourLeg.maxLoss: Net Debit Paid - (K2 - K1) (if positive, usually near zero or small loss after costs)
fourLeg.breakeven: N/A (Payoff is constant at K2 - K1)
fourLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5960 Call for 93.75 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 83.25 (Bid), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 109.50 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5960 Put for 100.00 (Bid). Net Debit: (93.75 + 109.50) - (83.25 + 100.00) = 203.25 - 183.25 = 20.00. Value at Expiration = 5970 - 5960 = 10. Profit = 10 - 20.00 = -10.00.

fourLeg.name: Short Call Condor (Credit)
fourLeg.description: Defined-risk, defined-profit strategy selling two inner calls and buying two outer calls (same expiration, equidistant strikes K1<K2<K3<K4). Profits if the underlying price stays between K2 and K3 at expiration. Similar to a Short Strangle but with defined risk. Typically entered for a net credit.
fourLeg.notes: K1 < K2 < K3 < K4, often equidistant strikes. K2 and K3 are typically near current price.
fourLeg.maxLoss: Width of Inner Spread (K2 - K1 or K4 - K3) - Net Credit Received
fourLeg.breakeven: Lower: K2 - Net Credit Received; Upper: K3 + Net Credit Received
fourLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5950 Call for 99.25 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 83.25 (Bid), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5980 Call for 78.00 (Bid), Buy 1 MES JUN13 6000 Call for 73.25 (Ask). Net Debit: (99.25 + 73.25) - (83.25 + 78.00) = 172.50 - 161.25 = 11.25. (Note: This example results in a Net Debit based on MES data).

about.title: About This Tool
content: This page provides information and payoff diagrams for various option strategies, categorized by the number of 'legs' (individual option contracts) involved.
The examples use MES (Micro E-mini S&P 500) option prices from the provided screenshot (June 13 expiration data) for illustration.
The payoff diagrams illustrate the theoretical profit or loss of each strategy *at expiration* based on the price of the underlying asset. They are generated using Plotly.js.

Please note that real-world premiums vary based on volatility, time to expiration, interest rates, and market conditions. The bid/ask spread can significantly impact the actual cost or credit received, as seen in some examples resulting in a debit where the strategy description typically implies a credit.

Disclaimer: This information is strictly for educational purposes and does not constitute financial advice. Option trading involves significant risk and is not suitable for all investors. Consult with a qualified financial professional before trading options.
